answers.answer: I believe valve replacements have vastly improved over the last 15 years.  Materials are better and doctors have more expertise.  I would get a second opinion just to make sure he is a good candidate and the problem is serious enough to be compromising the years he has left.  It is a tough decision I know.  My grandmother is 88 and we really have to weigh the options every time she has to have any type of procedure.Best of luck to you and your dad!

This is from the Merck Manual of Geriatrics, Ch. 96, Section on Valve Replacement (you can google to read the entire article):"Extended long-term survival and symptomatic relief in a symptomatic elderly patient (even in a nonagenarian) with severe valvular heart disease are usually obtained using aortic valve replacement. The long-term survival rate with valve replacement--about 70% at 5 years--appears far superior to that attainable with drug therapy alone. The survival rate for elderly patients undergoing successful operations is similar to that for an age-matched population without valvular disease. "and"The overall perioperative mortality rate for aortic valve replacement in elderly patients is 10.5%"

question: My father needs by pass surgery and an aortic valve replacement.  The surgeon says that it is 'reasonable' that my father would make it through the surgery.  He suffers from Diabetes and Parkinson's Disease (mild tremors) as well.  I am not only concerned about the surgery but if he will make it through the recuperation in the hospital.  My Grandmother had the exact same surgery and lived for only 10 days, that was in 1991.If there is anyone out there with information regarding 85 year old patients that have had this surgery and is doing fine, I would love to know.
title: Valve replacement for 85 year old male
